segments.text: This interview with Father Dennis Farkasvalve took place on November 20, 1982, at the Cistercian Abbey of Our Lady of Dallas in Irving, Texas.
The interviewer is Michael Burns.
This interview concerns Father Dennis' interpretation of the Hungarian Revolt of October of 1956, at which he was present.
Father Dennis Farkasvalve,
How old were you when the revolution in Hungary started?
20 years old and I was in third year of law school at the University of Budapest.
Okay, could you explain to me your role in the revolution?
I don't think that I played a role, although I might say that I have done exactly what the
hundreds and thousands of university students and high school students did.
Namely, I participated in the first large demonstration that has been the beginning of the revolution.
And later on I also participated in a few more gatherings.
One particular gathering that was at the university itself, at which certain decisions were made and a new leadership was elected.
But I have even received arms at the university, but after about half an hour of thinking it over, I decided that I'm not going to participate in the fighting.
I felt that there was actually no chance of success, and I did not feel that there was any point of risking more lives.
Okay.
I'd like to talk about the feelings and the moods leading up to the revolution.

well the feelings and the moods go back probably to the middle of the summer of 1956 there was an erosion of the terror system in Hungary and also there was a feeling that the party itself was divided and the liberal wing
liberal in the sense of asking for more individual rights, more democracy in the country, emerged.
And as a consequence, the school year has started in a mood quite different from previous school years.
The well-known burial of Laszlo Roik
was the first event which has seen some sporadic demonstrations in the city of Budapest, but information about it came only through rumors.
And then in the middle of October, in the city of Szeged, which is the second largest city of Hungary, about 100 miles from Budapest,
a city with a university, the students have started a movement that was supposed to be the substitute movement for the communist youth movement.
So, maybe very similarly to what is going on now in Poland, that a trade union organization
free trade union organization wants to substitute for the communist-run trade union movement.
In Hungary, the youth movement and the movement of university students was supposed to replace the party-run
youth movement that was of course corrupt and totally under the influence of the party leadership.
Now, this was an organization that tried to spread the demands of the youth among the students, demands for more democracy, a new government, and more freedom.
Two days before

I think two days before the revolution itself, so on the 21st of October, if I remember correctly, a delegation from the University of Szeged came to our university and gave a short speech expressing and describing the goals for which this new youth movement started.

The professors, who at the law school were all members of the party, did not know really how to react, and they obviously did not receive any orders from the party what to do about this new youth movement, which obviously has had some support from the party itself.
You might also remember that at the same time, in Poland,
there was unrest in Gdansk.
And so this youth movement has called for a protest march, or actually for a sympathy march on behalf of the Polish workers.
That was the excuse or motive under which the large demonstration of October the 23rd, 1956 was called.
And that demonstration turned into a revolution.
Okay.
That demonstration was announced, I think, a day early, on Tuesday the 22nd, and on Wednesday the 23rd, at 3 o'clock we were supposed to be at the statue of Pateufi on the shore of the Danube.
And that's where I also showed up, and our protest march started through the whole city.
Okay.
In this, in the march in the crowd, was it, in crowds, a lot, many times you get a feeling of chaos or just heat of the moment?
No, the march was very well organized in the sense that it was very orderly, and there were banners and flags, banners identifying each group, and actually there are three, four large universities
scattered in the city of Budapest.
So from each university, practically all students gathered and in very orderly fashion moved across the city to the posted goal of the demonstration, the statue of Bem,
General Bem was a Polish general in the anti-Habsburg revolution of 1848.

And since this was a sympathy march for the Polish, the idea was that we would all gather at the statue of this Polish general, who 100 years or 130 years, 120 years earlier, helped the Hungarians in their fight against the Austrians.

now the march was also in a way very ironically composed because all the professors all the communists of the university participated so obviously they got from the party the order to partake in order to keep it under control
and in order to watch who is doing the so-called provocations, that is, who is going to start the anti-Soviet slogans.

I personally thought that all the slogans that were shouted for more democracy and this sort of thing was hogwash, till we finally reached, oh, maybe three-quarters of the route on the bridge of St. Margaret.

passing from one side of the Danube to the other, it was at that place that I started, that I heard the first anti-Soviet slogan, and honestly, my feeling was, now you're talking, because that's the issue, when the famous Russkikhaza, Russians go home, slogan started.
From then on, that has become the central issue of the demonstration.
In other words,

that whatever what was buried in everybody's heart the main complaint and main problem of the country erupted in the middle of the demonstration spontaneously and at least my feeling was that it has erupted spontaneously by the time we have reached the square where the statue of General Bem stands

the university students picked up thousands of workers office and store personnel I mean people who populated the streets and the offices and the workplaces which we passed by we just picked up we we have doubled or tripled our membership in other words we just
drew people out of their homes and offices and workplaces, and the whole city ended up being on the streets.
So the university students were maybe just a match to the fire.
Okay.
Speaking of university students, it's been said that the Patafi Club was a group of intellectuals that started thinking of this and
Again, could you describe your involvement or your...
The Patufi Club was a group of dissident writers starting to meet during the summer and starting to work out a platform which of course was pretty much along the lines of

left-wing or even socialist or you might say communist ideology and yet they try to formulate a new way of socialism which would be catering to the national feelings of the country would be for more freedom
human rights or individual freedom and more independence in economic planning.
The platform being formulated by intellectuals was something I think utopian and as opposed to what is going on in Poland today, very much based on
an intellectual leadership rather than a trade union organization so led by workers.
I think a lot of workers participated, but as a second step.
The leadership element was left-wing writers, but left-wing writers who disagreed with the policies of the- or the official leadership of the party.
And that shows again
that there was a cracked party that allowed these developments.
The party leadership has been torn in two ever since the death of Stalin, which was in 1953.
So, the prehistory of the revolution is probably the internal confusion of the party which has allowed the emergence of a young, more liberal
wing within the party itself that has appealed on to the workers and especially the youth in order to change the system, change the internal composition of the leadership in Hungary.
They did not realize that
the majority of the Hungarians did not want communism at all.
In other words, this movement of the patriotic club has flipped into a nationwide revolution against the communist system as such, and against the Russians in particular.
Could you tell me about the Tearing Down of Stalin statue?
Were you there?
The statue of Stalin, I think, was an eyesore and a symbol of the suppression, for sure.
It stands in the middle of what is called the city park, and at considerable distance from my home.
After the demonstration at the statue of General Vem,
the swollen crowd on the streets took different directions.
I stayed with the group that went to the parliament and demanded that the previous prime minister, Imre Nagy, who was somehow the symbol of the more liberal element in the party, would talk to us.
So I stayed with that group, while other people went to the
statue of Stalin, and a third group went to the radio station, the official radio station.

Now, the group at the Stalin statue has worked a couple of hours in order to demolish the statue, but when the statue was on the ground, it was called for celebration, so the statue was dragged all across the city,
and finally got deposited across the National Theater in a side street in order not to block traffic.
Two or three days later, maybe it was more than two or three days later, I also paid my respects to the broken statue of Stalin.
There was still a standing crowd around it and people were chiseling little souvenir pieces from the statue for themselves.
little fragments of the statue of Stalin afterwards.
But I was unable to get one myself, but I've seen the statue and the sort of bonfire around it a few days after it was torn down.
Okay, Father Dennis, could you describe the massacre in Parliament Square?
The massacre in Parliament Square I think took place on the 25th of October.
After
a lull following the demonstrations and the first fights on the streets.
The first fight, really, first armed exchange between secret police and the revolutionaries took place at the radio, not at the parliament.
And that was still the night of the 23rd.

By the way, very few people know that this first fight was broadcast on the radio, because they forgot to turn off the microphones in the radio station, so that for about half an hour, and I listened to it through the radio, you could hear, besides classical music, shots and exchange of shots.
For about half an hour it was transmitted on the radio.
to the whole country.
That's how the country has learned everywhere about the revolution, that, you know, there was pandemonium in the radio station itself.
But that was the 23rd night.
Two days later, I think in the morning, at around 10 or 11 o'clock in the morning, a new demonstration was announced
and I have seen the people, at least one large group, moving through the fashionable street, actually in downtown Budapest, where I also lived, and I accompanied them for
quite a while we had some side demonstrations on the way.
But rumors said that armed resistance will wait for us at Parliament, so I returned home.
Again, my position and the position of my family was that precipitation of the revolution into armed conflict will only
foretell defeat.
There was no hope of coming out victorious from an armed confrontation with the Soviets.
That was the belief that I held and my family also held.
So, we promised each other not to get involved in the fights.
So, I came home.
Was this a minority view?
This was the, I must say, the intelligent view, the less passionate and more realistic view among the circles of my friends.
In any case, I went home and first a phone call came from friends telling that there is a massacre

in on the square in front of the parliament then two boys boyfriends of my sister arrived to our home who personally came from there and escaped with their lives and ran to our home we were not too far away from the from the
Parliament and they describe what has happened they were caught in the crossfire on the bridge a bridge that has been just a temporary bridge across the Danube in front of the Parliament
And right after the revolution, the bridge was demolished.
But these guys were hiding on the bridge and surviving the massacre between the columns of the bridge, which must have been eerie.
In any case, these people were eyewitnesses.
And while they were still in our home, we were able to watch from our windows
We were on the sixth floor of a large apartment complex and we were able to watch on the street truckloads of corpses being brought.

from the parliament square obviously to the morgue and that was eerie those corpses were just every everyday people just thrown on the trucks and being carried with incredible speed through the streets and they were not even covered so
It was probably the most scariest thing that I've seen in those weeks.
I'd like to ask you about the radio involvement.
It's the Voice of America Radio Free Europe.
Okay, well, of course, Free Europe played a very important part in our lives.
You must realize that starting in 1948, the country became completely isolated from both the West and the truth.
So, we did not receive information about international events, but through the censorship of the party.
So Radio Free Europe was a very important source of information.
The broadcasts were seriously disturbed, yet it was possible to listen to Free Europe.
and a lot of people picked up the information from Free Europe.

Now, Free Europe was considered by most of my contemporaries and friends as interesting and helpful, but irresponsible at the same time, making the West appear to us as an absolute paradise which is denied to us.
Also, the readiness of America in the Cold War to strike at the Russians was overplayed.

So there was a popular view widely spread all over the country that in case there is armed conflict between the people and the Russians in any of the satellite countries, there would be American intervention.

This has been so widely popular, held even by the leaders, even by Imre Nagy, the prime minister, that when the Russians on November the 4th have started their second major offensive against the revolution and have completely run over Hungary,
the last messages to the UN included appeals on paratroopers.
Now I wonder what kind of paratroopers they would be would have expected.
Of course Imre Nagy was talking to the UN not to the US, but in the minds of everybody else we were actually waiting for
paratroopers who actually helped from heaven, actually from the sky, to be dropped over us.
I did not believe in it personally, but a lot of people thought that American intervention was the only answer, the only logical answer to expect.
And I am sure that a lot of people in this country thought that an American intervention was in order.
So the disappointment was not only ours or that of my contemporaries at the time, but a lot of people here thought that letting down the Hungarian Revolution was the wrong decision by Eisenhower.
In my opinion, there was no chance for intervention for America, and sad as it appears to be, I don't think I was terribly surprised.
Frustrated, yes, but surprised, no.
So, do you believe the US, through Radio Free Europe, helped to inspire the revolution?
The US, by the Cold War alone, has certainly maintained the impression in Hungary
that we had powerful allies in our struggle against the Soviet, allies that were ready to fight in case that was necessary.
I don't think that the Hungarian public was sufficiently educated, and Free Europe didn't do the education, in the power play
that has just started called coexistence.
The word coexistence was just coined in the year in which the Hungarian Revolution took place.
Sadly enough, this is possibly not very well known in this country anymore, in 1955, less than a year earlier than the Hungarian Revolution,
the Austrian state was established.
That was the only time since Second World War that the Russians have ever stepped back, namely pulled out from a country.
Austria came about by

I think an agreement packed between the four powers to withdraw troops from Austria and establish a neutral state and the Russians who occupied one-fourth of Austria have also agreed to draw to pull back now that in that year the

the Western powers really made the decision of sealing the gains, the territorial gains of the Soviet after World War II, and our fate was also sealed, except we were not told about that, that with the establishment of the Austrian state, and blocking the entrance with the neutral state to the West, Hungary, Czechoslovakia, and Poland were
finally and definitely given over to the interest sphere of the Soviet.
And that has happened a year before the Hungarian Revolution.
Again, my parents, who probably were a little better educated than the average, were terribly aware
of what the establishment of Austria has meant.
When that was celebrated in Radio Vienna by the, in the opera of Vienna,
There was a great celebration and it was transmitted by radio.
My parents literally wept while listening to it on radio.
They knew that Austria has come about and Hungary got lost in that, in that, on that day.
So we, we were not kidding ourselves, but Free Europe did not
educate the public, and probably for good purpose, about this switch in Western policy.
So, that's what I think about it.
During the fighting itself, did you ever hear rumors that the U.S. was on the way?
And, I mean, people, it was said they were running through the streets yelling that, you know,
No, no, no, there were rumors about readiness of certain volunteer groups in Austria and in Germany, and that was, those rumors were actually well supported by facts.
There were private groups ready to come, and of course the major problem would have been
to cross any one of the neutral or communist countries.
Hungary was not contiguous with any member of NATO.
But Hungary is contiguous as the result of Second World War with the Soviet Union.
The Soviets have established the borders in such a way that they have direct access to all the satellite countries.
They don't have to cross another country in order to reach
Romania, Hungary, Czechoslovakia, Poland, or even Bulgaria.
And so it was very questionable how they would get through anybody.
There were rumors, however, if I'm not mistaken, that Eisenhower decided to come himself to Budapest.
Whether or not that rumor had anything behind it.
factual, I don't know, but of course Eisenhower didn't come.

The person who came was, and these are very famous people, the person who came was Brezhnev, who at the time was nobody, and ominously enough, the Hungarian ambassador, actually the Russian ambassador to Hungary at the time was
